Topics.Topic_name: Structure and function of the processor

Sub_topics.description: Know the roles of the Arithmetic and Logic Unit (ALU), Control Unit (CU) and key registers: Program Counter (PC), Accumulator (ACC), Memory Address Register (MAR), Memory Data Register (MDR), Current Instruction Register (CIR). Be able to explain what each register stores and why it is needed during program execution.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Buses and relation to assembly language
Sub_topics.description: Understand data, address and control buses: what each carries, direction of flow, and how bus activity relates to assembly language execution (e.g., moving instruction/data between memory and CPU).

Explain the Fetch–Decode–Execute cycle in detail, including changes to PC, MAR, MDR, CIR and ACC (where relevant): fetching instruction from memory, decoding in CU, executing via ALU/control signals, and storing results.
Explain factors affecting CPU performance: clock speed, number of cores, and cache (size/levels). Apply to scenarios to compare performance implications.
Understand pipelining as overlapping stages of instruction processing to improve throughput/efficiency; describe benefits and typical issues (e.g., hazards/stalls) at the conceptual level.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Processor architectures: Von Neumann vs Harvard vs contemporary
Sub_topics.description: Compare Von Neumann and Harvard architectures (shared vs separate instruction/data memory and buses) and relate to contemporary CPU features (e.g., caches, separate pathways) at a conceptual level.
Understand differences between CISC and RISC processors (instruction complexity, instruction count, execution cycles, typical trade-offs) and describe appropriate uses/contexts for each.

Explain what GPUs are and why they are effective for highly parallel workloads. Describe uses including non-graphics tasks (e.g., general-purpose parallel computation, AI/ML, simulation, cryptography).
Understand multicore CPUs and parallel systems; explain parallel execution conceptually and discuss benefits/trade-offs (performance scaling, concurrency overheads) in context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selecting I/O and storage devices for problems
Sub_topics.description: Apply knowledge of different input, output and storage devices to justify appropriate choices for given problem scenarios (considering performance, capacity, portability, reliability, cost, user needs).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic, flash and optical storage uses
Sub_topics.description: Describe how magnetic, flash (solid state) and optical storage work at a high level and justify typical uses (e.g., magnetic for large/cheap, SSD for speed/robustness, optical for distribution/archival).
Explain RAM and ROM: purpose, volatility, typical use in system operation (working memory vs firmware/boot code).
Understand virtual storage (secondary storage used to extend main memory); explain paging/swap conceptually and performance implications (thrashing, latency).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Operating systems: need, function and purpose
Sub_topics.description: Explain why an operating system is needed and its core functions/purpose (resource management, providing user interface, file management, device management, security, multitasking).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Memory management: paging, segmentation, virtual memory
Sub_topics.description: Understand memory management techniques: paging and segmentation (concepts, address translation at a high level) and virtual memory; explain benefits and drawbacks in context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interrupts and ISRs in the FDE cycle
Sub_topics.description: Explain interrupts, their role, and Interrupt Service Routines (ISR). Relate interrupt handling to the Fetch–Decode–Execute cycle (e.g., saving state, servicing, returning).

Compare scheduling strategies: round robin, first come first served (FCFS), multi-level feedback queues, shortest job first (SJF), shortest remaining time (SRT). Apply to scenarios (throughput, responsiveness, fairness, starvation).
Understand and distinguish distributed, embedded, multi-tasking, multi-user and real-time operating systems; describe typical use cases and constraints.
Explain BIOS purpose (firmware/boot process, hardware initialisation, bootstrapping OS) and its role in system startup.
Explain device drivers: what they do, why they are needed (hardware abstraction/OS-device communication), and typical issues (compatibility, updates).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Virtual machines and emulation of machine functions
Sub_topics.description: Understand virtual machines: software providing the function of a machine, including executing intermediate code (e.g., bytecode) and running an operating system within another; explain benefits (portability, isolation, testing) and costs (overhead).
Understand what applications software is and be able to justify selecting suitable applications for a specific purpose (features, platform constraints, user needs).
Explain utility software (e.g., backup, antivirus, compression tools) and their functions in maintaining/optimising systems.
Compare open source and closed source software: licensing, source availability, development models, security/quality considerations, cost, support; apply to contexts.
Distinguish interpreters, compilers and assemblers: how they translate code, when translation occurs, typical outputs (machine code, bytecode), and implications (speed, debugging, portability).
Understand compilation stages: lexical analysis (tokenising), syntax analysis (parsing), code generation, and optimisation; explain purpose of each stage.
Explain linkers and loaders and how libraries are used; understand linking (combining object code and libraries), loading into memory, and resolving external references.
Understand software development approaches: waterfall lifecycle, agile methodologies, extreme programming (XP), spiral model and rapid application development (RAD).
Evaluate relative merits and drawbacks of waterfall, agile/XP, spiral and RAD, and decide when each might be used (risk, requirements volatility, stakeholder involvement, delivery speed).
Be able to write, trace and follow algorithms accurately (step-by-step logic, correctness, and clarity), including in preparation for coding.
Understand why different programming paradigms exist and identify key characteristics/uses of different paradigms (e.g., procedural, object-oriented, low-level/assembly).
Understand procedural/imperative languages: sequence, selection, iteration, procedures/functions, state and variables; apply to describing program structure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Assembly language and Little Man Computer (LMC)
Sub_topics.description: Understand assembly language concepts and be able to follow and write simple programs using the Little Man Computer (LMC) instruction set (e.g., ADD, SUB, STA/STO, LDA/LOAD, BRA/BR, BRZ/BZ, BRP/BP, INP, OUT, HLT/COB/END, DAT).
Understand modes of addressing memory: immediate, direct, indirect and indexed; explain how the operand is obtained and why each mode is useful.
Understand OOP concepts and terminology: classes, objects, methods, attributes, inheritance, encapsulation and polymorphism; be able to interpret and design simple class structures and interactions.
Distinguish lossy and lossless compression; explain typical use cases, trade-offs (quality vs size), and implications for data reconstruction.
Understand and apply run-length encoding for lossless compression; be able to encode and decode simple data sequences.
Understand dictionary-based lossless compression (building/using a dictionary of repeated patterns/strings); be able to describe and apply to examples at a conceptual level.
Understand symmetric encryption: same key used to encrypt/decrypt; describe benefits/limitations (key distribution) and typical use cases.
Understand asymmetric (public/private key) encryption: how keys are used for confidentiality and key exchange; compare to symmetric encryption conceptually.
Explain hashing and different uses (e.g., password storage/verification, integrity checks, digital signatures support, indexing/lookup). Understand one-way property and collision conceptually.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Database models and keys (relational/flat file; PK/FK/secondary)
Sub_topics.description: Understand flat-file vs relational databases. Define and apply key concepts: primary key, foreign key, secondary key; explain how keys support relationships and retrieval.
Understand entity relationship modelling (entities, relationships and cardinalities) and be able to interpret/construct ER models consistent with OCR ERD conventions.
Explain indexing: why it is used to speed up queries, basic trade-offs (extra storage and slower writes), and contexts where indexing is beneficial.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Capturing, selecting, managing and exchanging data
Sub_topics.description: Understand methods of capturing, selecting, managing and exchanging data (data collection approaches, validation, data management practices, data interchange considerations).
Understand and apply normalisation up to 3NF: identify repeating groups, partial and transitive dependencies; decompose tables to reduce redundancy and anomalies.

Be able to interpret and write/modify SQL using required constructs (as per OCR guidance): SELECT (including nested SELECTs), FROM, WHERE, LIKE, AND, OR, JOIN (INNER JOIN), DELETE, INSERT, DROP; use wildcards ‘*’ and ‘%’ appropriately where relevant in OCR contexts.
Understand referential integrity: ensuring foreign keys reference existing primary keys; effects of insert/update/delete; why constraints prevent orphan records.
Understand transaction processing and ACID properties: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability; explain why these matter for correctness and reliability.
Explain record locking in concurrent database access and how it prevents conflicts; understand redundancy and its relationship to normalisation and reliability (including risks of inconsistency).
Understand characteristics of networks (e.g., topology/scale/performance) and explain why protocols and standards are essential for interoperability and reliable communication.
Understand the internet structure using the TCP/IP stack and protocol layering: roles of layers, encapsulation, and why layering is used.
Explain Domain Name System (DNS): translating domain names to IP addresses, hierarchical structure, and why caching affects performance.
Distinguish LANs and WANs: scale, ownership, typical technologies and performance considerations.
Compare packet switching and circuit switching; explain implications for reliability, latency, throughput and suitability for different applications.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Network security threats; firewalls, proxies, encryption
Sub_topics.description: Understand common network security threats (conceptual) and how firewalls, proxies and encryption mitigate risks; apply to scenario-based reasoning.
Identify and explain roles of network hardware (e.g., switches, routers, access points, NICs) at an appropriate conceptual level for A Level.
Compare client-server and peer-to-peer architectures; explain advantages/disadvantages and suitable use cases.

Understand and use core HTML tags per OCR guidance: , , , <body>, headings <h1>/<h2>/<h3>, <img> (src, alt, height, width), <a> (href), <div>, <form>, <input type="text" name=... and <input type="submit">, <p>, lists <li>, <ol>, <ul>, and <script>. Be able to interpret and write simple HTML structures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: CSS styling (inline, external, selectors and properties)
Sub_topics.description: Understand CSS used inline via style attribute and via external stylesheets. Use element selectors (e.g., h1{...}), class selectors (e.g., .infoBox{...}), and id selectors (e.g., #menu{...}). Know required properties: background-color, border-color, border-style, border-width, color (named and hex), font-family, font-size, height, width; apply to create and interpret styling.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: JavaScript basics (control structures and DOM output)
Sub_topics.description: Be able to follow and write basic JavaScript using equivalent control structures to OCR pseudocode (sequence/selection/iteration, variables, expressions). Understand input via reading form values (method given in questions) and output methods: document.getElementById(...).innerHTML=..., document.write(...), alert(...). Minor syntax inaccuracies not penalised; focus on logic.
Explain how search engines index web pages (crawling, building an index of terms/metadata/links) and implications for retrieval and ranking.
Understand the idea of the PageRank algorithm: ranking pages using link structure/importance; be able to explain conceptually how inbound links contribute to rank.
Distinguish server-side and client-side processing; explain where code runs, what tasks suit each (security, performance, user interaction), and impacts on latency and scalability.
Know and use primitive data types: integer, real/floating point, character, string and Boolean; select appropriate types for given data and constraints.
Represent positive integers in binary; understand place value and convert simple values to/from denary.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Negative numbers: sign-and-magnitude and two’s complement
Sub_topics.description: Understand sign-and-magnitude and two’s complement representations; convert negative denary integers to binary and interpret given binary values.
Perform addition and subtraction of binary integers (including with two’s complement where relevant); identify overflow conceptually.
Represent positive integers in hexadecimal; understand base-16 place value and digit mapping (0–9, A–F).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Convert between denary, binary and hexadecimal
Sub_topics.description: Convert positive integers between binary, hexadecimal and denary; use grouping of bits (nibbles) for binary↔hex conversion.
Understand floating point representation in binary (sign, exponent, mantissa/significand) and normalisation; convert simple values and explain precision limits.
Carry out floating point addition and subtraction conceptually: aligning exponents, operating on mantissas, renormalising; include positive and negative numbers.
Use bitwise operations and masks: shifts, AND, OR, XOR to combine/manipulate bits; apply to setting/clearing/toggling bits and extracting fields.
Explain how character sets (ASCII and Unicode) represent text; understand why Unicode is needed and implications for storage/encoding.
Understand arrays (0-based where relevant in OCR pseudocode), including up to 3 dimensions; access/update elements; explain typical uses and limitations.
Understand records (structured fields), lists (dynamic sequences) and tuples (fixed-size ordered collections); choose appropriate structures for problems.
Understand linked lists: node structure and pointers/references; be able to create, traverse, add and remove nodes conceptually/with pseudocode.
Understand stack ADT (LIFO) operations: push, pop, peek/top; implement or describe using arrays or linked structures; apply to use cases (e.g., call stack, undo).
Understand queue ADT (FIFO) operations: enqueue, dequeue, front/rear; implement or describe (array/circular buffer or linked) and apply to scenarios (e.g., scheduling).
Understand tree terminology (root, node, edge, parent/child, leaf, subtree, depth/height). Create and traverse trees; add/remove nodes at a conceptual/algorithmic level.
Understand binary search tree property and operations: search, insert, delete (conceptual), and traversal; evaluate efficiency implications.
Understand graphs: vertices/nodes and edges; directed vs undirected; represent graphs (e.g., adjacency list/matrix conceptually) and traverse/explore at an algorithmic level.
Understand hash tables: hashing to map keys to indices, collision concept and typical handling approaches (conceptual); create, insert, search and delete at a high level.

Be able to create, traverse, add data to and remove data from the listed data structures (arrays, records/lists/tuples, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees/BSTs, graphs, hash tables) using either arrays/procedural techniques or an object-oriented approach as appropriate.
Define and model problems using Boolean logic/expressions; use appropriate operators and clearly express conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Simplifying Boolean expressions with Karnaugh maps
Sub_topics.description: Manipulate and simplify Boolean expressions, including use of Karnaugh maps (K-maps) to minimise expressions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Boolean algebra laws (De Morgan, distribution, etc.)
Sub_topics.description: Use Boolean algebra rules to derive/simplify expressions: De Morgan’s Laws, distribution, association, commutation, double negation; show correct symbolic manipulation.
Interpret and construct logic gate diagrams and truth tables; map between expressions, truth tables and gate-level implementations (AND, OR, NOT, XOR as required).
Understand the logic/behaviour of D-type flip-flops (latching on clock edge) and how they store state in digital systems at a conceptual level.
Understand half adder and full adder logic; be able to derive outputs (Sum/Carry) from truth tables and relate to binary addition circuits.
Understand requirements and implications of the Data Protection Act 1998 in computing contexts (personal data handling, compliance responsibilities, risks of misuse).
Understand the Computer Misuse Act 1990: offences related to unauthorised access, unauthorised modification, and related cybercrime; apply to scenarios.
Understand the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 as it applies to software and digital content: ownership, copying/licensing, infringement and consequences.
Understand the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000: lawful interception/monitoring powers and implications for privacy and communications data in computing contexts.
Evaluate moral/social/ethical impacts of computers in the workforce: automation, job displacement/creation, deskilling/reskilling, productivity and wellbeing implications.
Analyse ethical issues of automated decision making: bias, transparency, accountability, explainability, error handling and appeal processes.
Discuss opportunities and risks of AI: fairness, safety, misuse, reliability, dependency, and societal impacts; apply ethical reasoning to examples.
Evaluate environmental effects: energy use, e-waste, resource extraction, sustainability of data centres and devices; trade-offs and mitigation strategies.
Discuss censorship online: motivations (legal, political, safety), methods, impacts on freedom of speech, access to information, and societal consequences.
Analyse monitoring of behaviour (surveillance, tracking, workplace/school monitoring): consent, proportionality, privacy, security benefits vs harms.
Discuss collection and analysis of personal information (profiling, targeted advertising): data ethics, privacy, informed consent, anonymisation limits and risk.
Evaluate issues of piracy (intellectual property infringement) and offensive communications online: legal/ethical consequences, moderation, harms and responsibilities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Layout, colour paradigms and character sets (cultural issues)
Sub_topics.description: Understand cultural/usability issues in digital systems relating to layout, colour paradigms (meaning/accessibility across cultures) and character sets (language support, inclusivity).
Understand what abstraction is in computational thinking: reducing complexity by focusing on essential details while omitting irrelevant information.
Explain why abstraction is needed (manage complexity, improve understanding, enable generalisation/reuse, support modelling).
Understand differences between an abstraction and reality; explain limitations/assumptions and how they affect validity of solutions/models.
Devise an abstract model for varied situations (identifying entities, attributes, relationships, constraints) suitable for computational solutions.
Identify required inputs and outputs for a given problem situation, including data types/ranges where relevant.
Determine preconditions for devising a solution (assumptions, constraints, required resources, initial states) and how they affect algorithm design.
Understand caching conceptually (storing results/data for reuse) and evaluate benefits (speed) and drawbacks (staleness, memory usage, invalidation complexity).
Explain the need for reusable components (functions, modules, classes) and how reuse supports maintainability, reliability and efficiency of development.
Identify the components of a problem (data, processes, constraints) in preparation for computational solution design.
Identify components of a solution (subtasks, modules, data structures, algorithms) and how they fit together.
Determine the correct order of steps needed to solve a problem; express as algorithmic sequence and justify ordering constraints.
Identify sub-procedures necessary to solve a problem; define clear interfaces (parameters/returns) and responsibilities.
Identify points in an algorithm/program where decisions must be taken (branching) and the consequences for control flow.
Determine logical conditions that affect decision outcomes; construct Boolean expressions and reason about truth conditions.
Determine how decisions affect program flow (paths, loops, termination) and be able to trace execution for given inputs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify concurrent parts of a problem
Sub_topics.description: Determine which parts of a problem can be tackled at the same time (parallelisable tasks) and identify dependencies/synchronisation needs conceptually.
Outline benefits and trade-offs of concurrent processing in context (speed-up, responsiveness vs overheads, complexity, race conditions/resource contention at a conceptual level).
Use and reason about core programming constructs: sequence, iteration (count- and condition-controlled), and branching/selection (if/else, switch/case).
Understand recursion: how it works (base case, recursive step, call stack conceptually), where it is used, and compare to iterative approaches (clarity, performance, memory).
Understand scope: global and local variables; explain lifetime/visibility and risks (side effects) vs benefits (shared state).
Understand modularity via functions/procedures. Use parameters and returns appropriately. Understand passing by value vs by reference and effects on data/mutability.
Use an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) to develop and debug programs: breakpoints, stepping, variable inspection, error messages, testing tools.
Apply object-oriented techniques in writing programs (classes/objects, encapsulation, methods/attributes, inheritance/polymorphism where appropriate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: What makes a problem computationally solvable
Sub_topics.description: Explain features that make a problem solvable by computational methods (definable inputs/outputs, algorithmic steps, constraints, decidability/feasibility at A Level).
Recognise and classify problems that can be addressed computationally; identify patterns and suitable known approaches.
Decompose problems into subproblems suitable for computational solutions; specify interfaces and manage dependencies.
Understand divide and conquer approach: split problem, solve subproblems, combine results; identify where suitable and benefits for efficiency.
Apply abstraction to simplify problems/solutions (data models, interfaces, generalised algorithms) and justify abstraction choices.
Apply backtracking conceptually to solve problems (searching decision tree, undoing choices when constraints violated); recognise suitable problem types (e.g., puzzles/constraint satisfaction).
Understand data mining at a conceptual level: extracting patterns/knowledge from large datasets; typical tasks (classification, clustering, association) and limitations/ethics link.
Understand heuristics as approximate/rule-of-thumb methods to find good solutions where exact methods are too slow; evaluate trade-offs (speed vs optimality).
Understand performance modelling: estimating/analysing system/algorithm performance using models/assumptions; apply to compare options conceptually.
Apply pipelining concept (staged processing) as a computational method beyond CPU architecture, where relevant to improving throughput in processes.
Use visualisation conceptually to aid problem solving and understanding of data/algorithms (graphs/charts/diagrams) and evaluate effectiveness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Algorithm analysis and design for situations
Sub_topics.description: Analyse requirements and design algorithms appropriate to a given situation; express using pseudocode/structured description and justify design choices.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Algorithm suitability: time vs space trade-offs
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate suitability of different algorithms for a task/dataset in terms of execution time and space; understand trade-offs and constraints.

Understand measures/methods to determine algorithm efficiency using Big O notation: constant O(1), linear O(n), polynomial O(n^k), logarithmic O(log n), exponential O(2^n) (or similar). Be able to assign/justify complexity for simple algorithms.
Compare complexities of algorithms and interpret what differences mean for performance as input size scales; select better algorithm for constraints.
Know and apply algorithms for stacks and queues (push/pop/peek; enqueue/dequeue) and be able to trace or implement them with suitable structures.
Understand and apply depth-first traversal (post-order) and breadth-first traversal of trees; be able to trace order and implement conceptually (e.g., recursion/stack for DFS, queue for BFS).
Understand and apply bubble sort; trace passes, swaps and determine complexity; identify when it is inefficient.
Understand and apply insertion sort; trace insertion steps, determine complexity characteristics and appropriate contexts (nearly sorted lists).
Understand merge sort as divide-and-conquer; trace splitting/merging, understand time/space complexity implications.
Understand quick sort; partitioning around pivot, recursion; discuss average vs worst-case complexity conceptually and recursion depth considerations.
Understand linear search; trace and identify time complexity O(n); know when used (unsorted data).
Understand binary search on sorted data; trace midpoints and comparisons; identify time complexity O(log n) and precondition of sorted list.
Understand and apply Dijkstra’s algorithm for shortest paths in weighted graphs with non-negative edge weights; trace steps (tentative distances, visited set) and interpret results.
Understand A* pathfinding: uses cost-so-far + heuristic estimate; explain role of heuristic, admissibility conceptually, and compare with Dijkstra in purpose/performance.
Describe and justify features that make the chosen project problem solvable by computational methods, and explain why it is amenable to a computational approach.
Identify and describe stakeholders (individuals, groups, or personas) who have an interest in the solution; explain how they will use it and why it meets their needs.

Research the problem and existing/similar solutions to identify suitable approaches; describe essential features of a computational solution and justify choices; explain limitations of the proposed solution.
Specify and justify solution requirements (including hardware/software configuration if appropriate) and identify measurable, justified success criteria for evaluating the final solution.
Break down the project problem into smaller parts suitable for computational solutions; justify decomposition decisions and how parts support an overall solution.
Explain and justify the overall structure/architecture of the solution (modules/components/classes, data flow, interfaces) appropriate to the problem and users.
Describe solution parts using algorithms (pseudocode/flow/structured English) and justify how they integrate into a complete solution to the problem.
Describe usability features to be included (UI layout, accessibility, feedback, navigation, error messages) and relate to stakeholder needs.
Identify key variables, data structures and/or classes; justify choices and specify necessary validation (type/range checks, presence checks, constraints).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Test plan and test data selection
Sub_topics.description: Identify and justify test data for iterative development and post-development testing, including normal/boundary/erroneous cases as appropriate; explain how tests support validation of requirements and success criteria.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Iterative development with evidence and prototypes
Sub_topics.description: Provide annotated evidence of each stage of iterative development (aligned to agile principles), including prototype versions; justify key decisions and show progression from analysis/design to implementation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Testing during development and remedial actions
Sub_topics.description: Provide annotated evidence of testing at each stage of development with justification for each test; record failed tests and document remedial actions taken with reasoning/justification.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Post-development testing: function, robustness and usability
Sub_topics.description: Provide annotated evidence of end-of-development testing for robustness and function, plus usability testing via user feedback; explain how evidence was collected and what it shows.

Use development and post-development test evidence to evaluate the completed solution against the measurable success criteria defined in analysis; state whether each criterion is met/partially met/unmet with evidence-based reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evaluate usability features in final product
Sub_topics.description: Provide annotated evidence of implemented usability features and comment on their effectiveness; identify improvements where usability is only partially successful.

Discuss maintainability (code structure, readability, documentation, modularity, naming, extensibility) and propose realistic further development/improvements addressing limitations and new requirements.
